intro:
The Climate Negotiation Browser allows the user to navigate over 20 years of UN climate negotiations as captured by the Earth Negotiation Bulletin reporting system

The DISCOVER interface offers a visual overview of the most visible issues and actors of the negotiations.
The EXPLORE interface allows the user to search, filter and read verbatim text directly from ENB.

1.title: Visibility of issues related to Kyoto Protocol
1.analysis: The diagram shows the evolution of visibility of four discussions related to the Kyoto protocol (measured as the percentage of ENB sections mentioning expressions related to each discussion over the total of ENB sections for the year).

1.title: 1995 | USA | New York - ESTABLISHMENT OF THE INC/FCCC
1.content: On 11 December 1990, the 45th session of the UN General Assembly adopted a resolution that established the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee for a Framework Convention on Climate Change with the mandate of the INC/FCCC was to prepare an effective framework convention on climate change...

2.title: 1996 | Switzerland | Geneva - COOPERATION WITH THE IPCC
2.content: The US, supported by UZBEKISTAN, said IPCC technical reports should address a variety of gas mixes, time horizons and stabilization levels, use simple models to predict mean temperature change and sea-level rise...

3.title: 1997 | Japan | Kyoto - CLOSING PLENARY
3.content: COW Chair said he was happy to submit a Kyoto Protocol that was unanimously recommended for adoption by COP-3. He stated that the Protocol would reduce overall GHG emissions by 5.2% for Annex I Parties from 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012...

2.title: Setting up the Kyoto Protocol
2.analysis: The first stage of negotiations was framed by attempts to establish the Kyoto protocol and to decide its functional rules and integration within the UNFCCC system (this second concern will remain highly important throughout the negotiations).

1.title: 1995 | USA | New York - PLENARY
1.content: The Plenary met Wednesday morning so that AOSIS could introduce its draft protocol and Germany could introduce its proposal for further elements of a protocol...

2.title: 1995 | USA | New York - AGENDA ITEM 7(b) ADEQUACY OF COMMITMENTS
2.content: New Zealand, Hungary, France (on behalf of the EU), Japan, Canada, Denmark, Switzerland, Norway, the Netherlands, Australia, Belgium, Sweden and Mexico said commitments under Article 4.2(a) and (b) are not sufficient...

3.title: 1995 | Switzerland | Geneva - AGENDA ITEM 5 POSSIBLE FEATURES OF A PROTOCOL OR ANOTHER LEGAL INSTRUMENT
3.content: The Chair urged delegates to discuss the links between the Convention and a protocol, the need for different institutional mechanisms, the character of any annexes and the need for additional proposals...

3.title: Compliance and enforcement
3.analysis: After the Kyoto Protocol approval, the discussion shifted to questions concerning the implementation of the agreements taken in Kyoto.

1.title: 1999 | Austria | Vienna - Range of Consequences of Non-Compliance/Automatic Consequences
1.content: The different possible consequences in international instruments range from making non-compliance publicly known, such as in human rights conventions, to making adverse inferences on the part of the Party that has not delivered requested information or to imposing sanctions...

2.title: 1999 | Austria | Vienna - COMPLIANCE SYSTEMS UNDER INTERNATIONAL TREATIES
2.content: The different steps in a compliance process were presented. The first step would involve a reporting system on environmental quality data, baselines and implementation of obligations...

3.title: 2000 | The Netherlands | The Hague - Compliance
3.content: A key element of the Kyoto Protocol is a compliance system that can determine whether countries have met their commitments under the Protocol, as well as deciding what should happen in cases of non-compliance...

4.title: Going beyond the Kyoto Protocol
4.analysis: In the last period, the limitations of the Kyoto Protocol (both temporal and in terms of the countries engaged) drive the discussion increasingly toward the search for a successor to the Protocol and – after the failure of the Copenhagen conference – to the temporary extension of the agreement.

1.title: 2008 | Indonesia | Bali - BALI ROADMAP
1.content: The most significant issue taken up during the Conference in Bali was the question of a multilateral framework to address climate change, when the Kyoto Protocol's first commitment period expires. Negotiators spent much of their time agreing on a 2-year process to finalize a post-2012 regime by Dec.2009...

2.title: 2008 | Indonesia | Bali - NEGOTIATING TRACKS
2.content: The Bali roadmap builds on negotiations on long-term issues launched at the Montreal Climate Change Conference. In addition to addressing the period after the Protocol's first commitment period, the Bali roadmap aims to mend some of the fractures in the climate regime, most notably the refusal of the United States to ratify the Protocol...

3.title: 2010 | Mexico | Canc√∫n PARTIES PROPOSALS FOR PROTOCOL AMENDMENTS
3.content: Grenada, for AOSIS, called for breaking the deadlocks in time for a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, including ambitious emission reduction targets...

1.title: Visibility of other negotiation issues
1.analysis: The diagram shows the evolution of the visibility of a selection of negotiation issues related to the costs and investments connected to climate change (measured as the percentage of ENB sections that mentions expressions related to each discussion over the total of ENB sections for the year).

3.title: 2013 | Poland | Warsaw - LOSS AND DAMAGE
3.content: The issue proved controversial and was forwarded for ministerial consultations. Several developed countries stated that loss and damage is part of the mitigation and adaptation continuum, whereas developing countries identified loss and damage as a separate issue...

2.title: The consequences of climate change and of its mitigation
2.analysis: The first period of the negotiations seems occupied by a prevalence of questions regarding negative consequences of global warming as well as the response measures introduced to mitigate it.

1.title: 1999 | Germany | Bonn - IMPLEMENTATION OF CONVENTION ARTICLES 4.8 AND 4.9 (ADVERSE EFFECTS)
1.content: The technical workshop will aim to identify factors that will determine the adverse effects of climate change and the impacts of implementing response measures. It will further consider the specific needs of the least developed countries...

3.title: The impacts of climate change and the funding of adaptation
3.analysis: Contrarily to what could be expected, the discussion over the mechanisms necessary to finance the adaptation of impending consequences of climate change begin before the reflection directly addressed to these impacts and the vulnerabilities connected to them.

4.title: REDD+ and Loss & Damage
4.analysis: In the last stages, it is possible to observe the emergence of specialized discussion about greenhouse sinks (in the particular the question of forests) and about the liabilities and compensation connected to the impact of climate change.

viz_3.title: Who are the climate negotiations actors?

1.title: Main negotiation groups
1.analysis: The diagram shows the visibility evolution of the most engaged negotiation groupings. Each line shows the percentage of ENB sections in which the name of the corresponding group is mentioned (over the total of ENB sections for the year).

2.title: The protagonists
2.analysis: Three groupings are consistent among the most visible actors of the negotiation: the European Union, the Group of 77 and China and the Alliance of Small Islands. The engagement of this last group is particularly interesting, as it derives directly from the specific vulnerability of these States to climate change.

3.title: On the rise
3.analysis: The diagram shows the increasing engagement of countries in the southern hemisphere, in particular the African group and the Independent Association of Latin America and the Caribbean, as well as the transversal Environmental Integrity Group.

4.title: The peak after Kyoto
4.analysis: A clear peak is visible in many lines during 1998 (particularly the EU and the G77 and China). The interpretation of this peak, taking place right after the adoption of the Kyoto Protocol, is not obvious: it may corresponds to the efforts of some negotiation groupings to encourage the implementation of the Kyoto protocol, but it may also derive from a change in the way the ENB reports on the negotiation.

5.title: Top-5 most visible countries per year
5.analysis: Considering the most visible countries in the different years of the negotiation, one can see the constant importance of the United States, China and Australia (the European Union has been not considered in this visualization). Other particularly visible countries are Japan, Saudi Arabia. Canada and Switzerland seems to ‘switch places’, as Canada disappears from the top positions after 2009, while Switzerland returns in 2006.
